proof:
Let $C_1, \dots, C_k$ be the connected components of the graph $(V_H, E_H \setminus E')$. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $C_1$ is the component with the highest total degree. The proof proceeds by considering two cases based on the total degree of $C_1$.

First, suppose that $\deg_H(C_1) < \frac{1}{2} \deg_H(V_H)$. Since $C_1$ is the largest component, this implies that for all $i$ from $1$ to $k$, we have $\deg_H(C_i) < \frac{1}{2} \deg_H(V_H)$. The set of removed edges $E'$ must contain all edges connecting these different components. By applying the expansion property to each component, we can lower bound the size of the cut between them, which gives $|E'| \ge \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^k \alpha \deg_H(C_i)$. This sum simplifies to $\alpha |E_H|$. This result contradicts the given condition that $|E'| < \theta|E_H|$, because we know $\theta < \alpha$. Therefore, this case cannot happen.

The only remaining possibility is that $\deg_H(C_1) \ge \frac{1}{2} \deg_H(V_H)$. In this scenario, the total degree of the union of all other components, $C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k$, must be less than or equal to half the total degree of the graph, i.e., $\deg_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) \le \deg_H(V_H)/2$. This allows us to apply the expansion property to the vertex set $C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k$. Since the edges in $E'$ must contain the cut between this set and $C_1$, we obtain the inequality:
$$|E'| \ge \alpha \deg_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) = \alpha(\deg_H(V_H) - \deg_H(C_1))$$
By rearranging this inequality, we get a lower bound on the total degree of $C_1$, which is $\deg_H(C_1) \ge \deg_H(V_H) - |E'|/\alpha$. This in turn implies the desired result, $\deg_H(C_1) \ge (1 - \frac{2\theta}{\alpha}) \deg_H(V_H)$.
